articles.headline: Fuel Without the Fossil
articles.snippet: Nipping at the heels of various companies using biological methods to develop fuels from plant matter is a new group of entrepreneurs who favor chemistry.
articles.abstract: Nipping at the heels of various companies using biological methods to develop fuels from plant matter is a new group of entrepreneurs who favor chemistry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Mitch Mandich proudly showed off his baby, a 150-foot contraption of tanks, valves, hoppers, augers and fans. It hissed. It gurgled. An incongruous smell wafted through the air, the scent of turpentine.

articles.headline: Stores See Shoppers in Retreat
articles.snippet: The nation’s big retail chains reported the weakest October in 12 years, blaming economic clouds that show no signs of lifting before the end of the year.
articles.abstract: The nation’s big retail chains reported the weakest October in 12 years, blaming economic clouds that show no signs of lifting before the end of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers have rendered a verdict on the coming holiday season: grim.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Warns of Worse Times in the Economy
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke told Congress that the economy is going to get worse before it gets better, a message that got a chilly reception from both Wall Street and politicians.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke told Congress that the economy is going to get worse before it gets better, a message that got a chilly reception from both Wall Street and politicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 — Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress on Thursday that the economy was going to get worse before it got better, a message that received a chilly reception from both Wall Street and politicians.

articles.headline: At Morgan Stanley, a New Focus on Succession
articles.snippet: After a $3.7 billion trading loss and amid growing public pressure on boards to have succession plans in place, the issue has become more urgent at Morgan Stanley.
articles.abstract: After a $3.7 billion trading loss and amid growing public pressure on boards to have succession plans in place, the issue has become more urgent at Morgan Stanley.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like all chief executives on Wall Street, John J. Mack has grappled with the question of who will succeed him.

articles.headline: Merck Agrees to Settle Vioxx Suits for $4.85 Billion
articles.snippet: Merck has agreed to settle 27,000 lawsuits by people who claim they or their family members suffered injury or died after taking the pain medication.
articles.abstract: Merck has agreed to settle 27,000 lawsuits by people who claim they or their family members suffered injury or died after taking the pain medication.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years after withdrawing its pain medication Vioxx from the market, Merck has agreed to pay $4.85 billion to settle 27,000 lawsuits by people who claim they or their family members suffered injury or died after taking the drug, according to two lawyers with direct knowledge of the matter.

articles.headline: Reading the Tea Leaves of Financial Statements
articles.snippet: Looking at the current subprime mortgage crisis through the haze of markets and credit.
articles.abstract: Looking at the current subprime mortgage crisis through the haze of markets and credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark-to-market accounting is one of those ideas that sound brilliant until you try to do it when there is no market. That’s where mark-to-model comes in: companies say things are worth what they ought to be worth.

articles.headline: Police Block Bhutto From Attending Rally
articles.snippet: Lines of police officers placed concrete barriers and barbed wire at the entrance road to the opposition leader’s house in Islamabad.
articles.abstract: Lines of police officers placed concrete barriers and barbed wire at the entrance road to the opposition leader’s house in Islamabad.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Friday, Nov. 9 — A day after President Bush called, Gen. Pervez Musharraf said Thursday that Pakistan’s parliamentary elections would be held before Feb. 15. But his security forces widened their crackdown and on Friday moved to prevent the leader of the main opposition party, Benazir Bhutto, from leaving her house to attend a mass protest planned for the afternoon.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and David Rohde

articles.headline: Trade Accord Causes a Split of Democrats
articles.snippet: Nearly half the Democrats in the House supported a trade deal with Peru, reopening a party fissure on trade policy.
articles.abstract: Nearly half the Democrats in the House supported a trade deal with Peru, reopening a party fissure on trade policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 — Has the Democratic Party gone soft on trade? Or has it opened a bitter internal split that could come back to haunt the party in the coming elections?

articles.headline: Mine Giant Rejects Bid From Rival
articles.snippet: Rio Tinto, the London- and Melbourne-based mining company, rejected a $140 billion bid Thursday from its rival, BHP Billiton — calling it too low.
articles.abstract: Rio Tinto, the London- and Melbourne-based mining company, rejected a $140 billion bid Thursday from its rival, BHP Billiton — calling it too low.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Nov. 8 — Underscoring the skyrocketing value of commodities amid increasingly tight supplies, Rio Tinto, the London- and Melbourne-based mining company, rejected a $140 billion bid Thursday from its rival, BHP Billiton — calling it too low. The move squelched, at least for now, what would have been one of the largest acquisitions in corporate history.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Wayne Arnold
